page.title: 10SELSFIELD COMMON II
page.content: In 1968 the{National Trust,}on payment of Â£35, agreed to allow the{Mid Sussex {Water Company}to build an underground reservoir to service the nearby water tower. The{South Eastern Electricity {Board}still pays the rent agreed in 1962, one shilling (5p) per pole leg, strut or stay and one shilling per 100 yards (92m) of overhead line. {Little Wildgoose Wood}nearby is named after{John Wyldegoose.}He was pardoned for his part in{Jack Cade's {rebellion}in 1450 and built a house here called{Wyldegooseland.}No trace of it remains.{Selsfield Place,}a Victorian house, stands near the probable site. Opposite the Common is{Selsfield {House,}an 18th century building. In the{London to Brighton cycle {rally}this year (1985) the Common was a popular resting place.
